IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Our mission is to encourage charitable giving, particularly endowment giving, to help ensure the continued vitality of those institutions and activities that promote Jewish identity or support a high quality of life throughout Southern Arizona and the Jewish world.
IRS990.MissionDescription: JCF is an affiliated corporation of the Jewish Federation of Southern Arizona. Our mission is to encourage charitable giving, particularly endowment giving, to help ensure the continued vitality of those institutions and activities that promote Jewish identity or support a high quality of life in Southern Arizona and throughout the Jewish world, and to manage those funds received in a prudent and effective manner. To accomplish its mission the Foundation promotes the value of planned giving; works cooperatively with non-profit agencies to encourage planned giving among their own constituencies; and distributes grants to meet community needs, according to donors' wishes.
IRS990.Description: ProgramsJCF provides services for individual donors and non-profit agencies that house funds with the Foundation, including fund investment, management and reporting; field of interest research; and consultations with professional advisors. Legacy planning options include Donor Advised Endowment Funds, Bequests, Charitable Gift Annuities, Insurance Policies, and more. We manage Donor Advised Funds (non-endowed) and teen philanthropy funds (B'nai Tzedek Tucson). We sponsor educational programs on estate planning, legacy planning and funding opportunities for donors and the Jewish community at large; along with continuing education seminars for professional advisors. There were no significant changes to our programs in 2010.Objectives for Fiscal Year Beginning January 1, 20111. Continue to fund worthy programs via grants and philanthropic distributions. 2. Continue to promote endowments to support the Jewish community's institutions in perpetuity. 3. Continue to promote legacy planning and encourage donors to support the organizations they care about in perpetuity.4. An emphasis will be placed on working with local agencies to encourage planned giving among their constituencies. (See Areivim grant award under accomplishments)AccomplishmentsIn 2010, provided allocations and grants to almost 300 charitable 501(c)(3) organizations that provide health, educational, cultural and social services. Grants made from net assets totaled approximately $3.3 million dollars.Presented tax workshops and an ethics seminar to professionals in the Tucson community. We were one of five foundations from across the county to be selected to receive the prestigious "Areivim" matching grant. Areivim, a two year project, was launched the last quarter of 2010. It is a partnership between the Jewish Community Foundation of Southern Arizona and participating organizations to build endowments for the future of the Jewish community. Participants will receive incentive grants, high-quality training and support, sample marketing materials, and other services during this initiative.Our number of active volunteers is approximately 100.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Part V, Line 4: Intended uses of the endowment fund.
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Endowments are held for donor restricted uses and donor advised purposes

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Grantmaker's Description of How Grants are Used
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Grants can only be distributed to 501(c)(3) organizations. Before distributions are made we check their 501(c)(3) status by requesting a copy of their IRS Determination Letter, contact information, and a copy of their mission statement. We obtain the organization's status on GuideStar's Charity Check, which combines information from the IRS Determination letter, the IRS Pub 78, and the IRS BMF (Business Master File) reports. [IRS Revenue Procedure 2009-32 allows grantors to rely on third-party resources, such as GuideStar Charity Check, to obtain required Business Master File (BMF) data concerning a potential grantee's public charity classification under section 509(a)(1),(2) or (3)]Our board approves all new organizations before distributions are made. Annually the board re-approves our entire list of organizations after we have verified that their 501(c)(3) status is still in good order.Distributions for grants made for restricted purposes are accompanied with a letter stating that the funds can only be used for that purpose. The letters also include the following notation: This grant is made to your organization through the Jewish Community Foundation of Southern Arizona. By accepting this check, your organization certifies to the Jewish Community Foundation that no tangible benefit, goods, or services are received by any individuals or entities connected with the above-mentioned gift. These funds cannot be used for meeting pledge obligations already made.Restricted purpose grants that are to be made annually from endowment funds require that the organization provide us with a report of how the funds were used before the next year's grant will be distributed.Grants awarded under our competitive grants program require periodic reporting including copies of invoices and other supporting document prior to distributing funds to insure funds are being used for the purpose intended.We do not make grants to individuals.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19: Other Organization Documents Publicly Available
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The policy of the Jewish Community Foundation is upon request, to make its audited financial statements and Conflict of Interest Policy available for viewing at the office of the Foundation.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c: Explanation of Monitoring and Enforcement of Conflicts
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annually every board member is asked to sign a Conflict of Interest Statement as well as complete a form which discloses certain personal and business relationships. The board makes it a practice to put the following reminder on every written agenda that reads: Board members must disclose any potential conflict of interest related to the following agenda as well as topics discussed during the meeting. Periodically board members are also verbally reminded at the meeting to disclose any potential conflicts. In addition all employees and committee members are also required to sign a Conflict of Interest Statement.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11: Form 990 Review Process
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board formally assigned the responsibility of reviewing and approving the Form 990 to the Finance Committee. The Finance Committee meets, reviews and approves prior to filing. If there are any significant issues, the Finance Committee will bring them to the Board for informational purposes or approval.
